target: ___ M h/o chronic systolic CHF (EF 40-45%), COPD, basal carcinoma nevus syndrome, recent hospitalization for malignant otitis externa presenting with respiratory failure requiring intubation in the ED. Treated with aggressive diuresis and improved. Extubated successfully and being discharged back to ___ for continued management of multiple medical problems. #Respiratory failure: VBG on arrival to ED was 7.___/31. Per report, patient was awake and expressed desire for intubation in the ED; he was intubated in the ED without complication. Given marked peripheral edema on exam, the patient's respiratory failure was thought to be secondary to acute CHF exacerbation and volume overload. There was also question of superimposed pneumonia, but patient did not have leukocytosis or fever (patient also on broad antibiotics - vancomycin and meropenem - prior to presentation for ear infection), so thought to be less important clinically. Patient was started on a lasix drip 20 mg/hr, and responded well to it with good urine output. With improvement in respiratory status, patient was extubated successfully. #Chronic systolic CHF/CAD: Thought to be secondary to past ischmic event based on segmental hypokinesis seen on TTE several weeks prior to admission. Metoprolol was held in the setting of acute CHF exacerbation. PO metoprolol was restarted at home dosing. Patient is being discharged on IV lasix 80 mg BID. ___ was not started given the report of increased creatinine in the past with ___, though it would be an appropriate medication for his CHF management. If his creatinine continues to improve with further diuresis, addition of ___ or spironolactone may be considered. #Hypoglycemia: Blood glucose was in ___ on admission; no diabetes medications on admission. Patient was maintained on D10 until he was extubated and was no longer NPO. Hypoglycemia resolved when patient was taking PO. #Goals of care: Patient was DNR/DNI on last admission but expressed desire for intubation in ED. Patient initially expressed a desire to be full code, but with continued discussion, stated that he would like to be DNR, but ok to intubate. Continued discussion with both the patient and his family would be useful. #Malignant otitis externa: Patient was hospitalized 2 weeks ago for otitis externa; he was still on IV vancomycin, IV meropenem, and tobramycin/dexamethasone ear drops on admission. Although the original 2-week abx courses ended on ___, IV meropenem and tobramycin were continued. Vancomycin was held for several days given high vancomycin troughs. Prior to discharge, his vancomycin and meropenem were discontinued and his outpatient ID team was notified of the decision. He will follow up with his ID team and ENT as an outpatient for further management. #Stage IV CKD: Cr was stable at 2.3-2.5 (prior baseline according to last discharge summary was 2.7 in ___. Home regimen of nephrocaps, sevelamer, and vitamin D were restarted after extubation. #COPD: Patient's home regimen of fluticasone-salmeterol and tiotropoium was continued. PRN ipratropium was discontinued given that the patient was also on tiotropium. Given the exam without a lot of wheeze, it was thought that his COPD was not the main contributor to his respiratory distress. #GERD: PO omeprazole held while on IV pantoprazole for stress ulcer prophylaxis; restarted after extubation. #BPH: PO tamsulosin restarted after extubation. #Glaucoma: home latanoprost, dorzolamide, and artificial tears were continued. #DM: reportedly diet-controlled and patient had period of hypoglycemia while he was NPO and intubated. Blood sugars ok while taking PO. #Anemia: PO iron and ascorbic acid were restarted after extubation. #Hyperlipidemia: PO atorvastatin was restarted after extubation. #HTN: Metoprolol was held in the setting of acute CHF exacerbation, but restarted after he was extubated and his symptoms improved. #Depression: PO citalopram and trazodone were restarted after extubation. TRANSITIONS IN CARE: 1. CODE STATUS: DNR, ok to re-intubate 2. CONTACTS: Patient's son (___) ___ 3. MEDICATION CHANGES: 1. CHANGE lasix to 80mg IV twice daily 2. STOP Heparin IV infusion 3. STOP meropenem 4. STOP sodium bicarb IV infusion 5. STOP vancomycin 6. STOP albuterol/ipratropium combination inhaler 7. START albuterol meter-dosed inhaler two puffs inhaled by mouth every 6 hours as needed for shortness of breath/wheeze 8. START metoprolol tartrate 25mg by mouth twice daily. 9. START atorvastatin 80mg by mouth once daily 10. START citalopram 40mg by mouth daily 11. START trazodone 100mg by mouth once nightly, and an extra 50mg by mouth once nightly as needed for insomnia. 12. START sevaelamer carbonate 800mg by mouth three times daily with meals 13. START nephrocaps. I cap by mouth daily 14. START docusate sodium 100mg by mouth twice daily 15. START ascorbic acid ___ by mouth twice daily 16. START ferrous sulfate 325mg by mouth daily 17. START cholecalciferol 400units by mouth daily 18. START heparin 5000units by subcutaneous injection three times daily Please continue all other medications as previously prescribed. 4. FOLLOW-UP APPOINTMENTS: Department: ___ When: ___ at 4:30 ___ With: ___ Building: ___ Campus: ___ Best Parking: ___ Department: CARDIAC SERVICES When: ___ at 1 ___ With: ___ Building: ___ Campus: ___ Best Parking: ___ Department: OTOLARYNGOLOGY-AUDIOLOGY When: ___ at 2:45 ___ With: ___ Building: ___ Campus: ___ Best Parking: ___ There is an appointment being arranged for radiation to the left ear on ___. This is being arranged by radiation oncology. 5. OUTSTANDING CLINICAL ISSUES: -please follow up electrolytes twice daily and renal function once daily until stabilized on diuretics -please follow-up with radiation oncology for arrangement of radiation therapy to left ear -management of left ear with topical antibiotics and per ID -maintenance of even-to-negative volume status
generated_summary: A 45-year-old woman with metastatic breast cancer presents with worsening back pain. Imaging shows compression fractures in the thoracic spine. She is receiving palliative radiation therapy. The patient's mental status is clear and cooperative. She is currently being treated with antibiotics for pneumonia. Her medications include meropenem, vancomycin, tobramycin, dexamethasone, mupirocin, fluticasone-salmeterol, tiotropium bromide, albuterol, furosemide, aspirin, metoprolol-tartrate, atorvastatin, dorzolamide, tamsulosin, latanoprost, artificial tears, citalopram, trazodone, omeprazole, sevelamer carbonate, bisacodyl, heparin, and a combination of bronchodilators and oral anticoagulants. The patient is expected to return home after discharge, but

input: <SEX> M <SERVICE> NEUROSURGERY <ALLERGIES> No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> h/a, Nausea <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> ___: Suboccipital Craniotomy and resection of ___ ventricular tumor. <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> This is a ___ years old right handed man with no significant medical history who presents to the ___ for further evaluation of a recent ___ ventricle mass that was picked up on his brain Mri. Patient was seen in the ___ on ___. During initial visit, MRI of spine was ordered. Spine MRI showed focal enhancement seen along the anterior surface of the spinal cord at T12 level and joint degenerative disease. Patient was also sent home on dexamethasone 2 mg bid. Today he reports improvement with headaches, rash. He denies any seizures or weakness, numbness or tingling. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> Vasectomy <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> NC <PERTINENT RESULTS> ___ MRI Brain- IMPRESSION: MRI performed for surgical planning with surface markers demonstrates a small inferior fourth ventricle tumor with subtle enhancement. ___ CT Brain- IMPRESSION: Expected post-operative changes status post suboccipital craniotomy including pneumocephalus and blood layering within the occipital horns of the lateral ventricles. A metallic density object within the cisterna magna is noted- correlate with surgical details if this is expected. ___ MRI Brain- IMPRESSION: 1. Punctate signal abnormality and slow diffusion in the right posteromedial aspect of the medulla, suggestive of a tiny acute infarct. 2. No evidence of residual tumor within the ___ ventricle. 3. Expected post-operative appearance, little changed since the head CT performed the previous day. <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> DEXAMETHASONE - 2 mg Tablet - 2 Tablet(s) by mouth 2 TABS TWICE/DAY <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. acetaminophen 325 mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO Q6H (every 6 hours) as needed for pain, T>38.5. Disp: *30 Tablet(s)* Refills: *6* 2. oxycodone-acetaminophen ___ mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO Q4H (every 4 hours) as needed for pain. Disp: *30 Tablet(s)* Refills: *0* 3. bisacodyl 5 mg Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.) Sig: Two (2) Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.) PO DAILY (Daily). Disp: *10 Tablet, Delayed Release (E.C.)(s)* Refills: *2* 4. docusate sodium 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO BID (2 times a day). Disp: *30 Capsule(s)* Refills: *2* 5. doxycycline hyclate 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO Q12H (every 12 hours) for 7 days. 6. dexamethasone 0.5 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO Q8hrs () for 1 days. Disp: *qs Tablet(s)* Refills: *0* 7. dexamethasone 0.5 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO Q12hrs () for 1 days. Disp: *qs Tablet(s)* Refills: *0* 8. dexamethasone 0.5 mg Tablet Sig: Two (2) Tablet PO Qday () for 1 days. Disp: *qs Tablet(s)* Refills: *0* 9. famotidine 20 mg Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO twice a day: While taking dexamethasone. Disp: *60 Tablet(s)* Refills: *2* <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home With Service Facility: ___ <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> Biopsy result pending. Results will be discussed at future follow-up appointment. <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Normal mental status and neurological function at time of discharge. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> General Instructions/Information -Have a friend/family member check your incision daily for signs of infection. -Take your pain medicine as prescribed. -Exercise should be limited to walking; no lifting, straining, or excessive bending. -Dressing may be removed on Day 2 after surgery. -If you have dissolvable sutures you may wash your hair and get your incision wet day 3 after surgery. You may shower before this time using a shower cap to cover your head. -If your wound was closed with staples or non-dissolvable sutures then you must wait until after they are removed to wash your hair. You may shower before this time using a shower cap to cover your head. -Increase your intake of fluids and fiber, as narcotic pain medicine can cause constipation. We generally recommend taking an over the counter stool softener, such as Docusate (Colace) & Senna while taking narcotic pain medication. -Unless directed by your doctor, do not take any anti-inflammatory medicines such as Motrin, Aspirin, Advil, and Ibuprofen etc. -If you have been prescribed Dilantin (Phenytoin) for anti-seizure medicine, take it as prescribed and follow up with laboratory blood drawing in one week. This can be drawn at your PCPÂ’s office, but please have the results faxed to ___. If you have been discharged on Keppra (Levetiracetam), you will not require blood work monitoring. -If you are being sent home on steroid medication, make sure you are taking a medication to protect your stomach (Prilosec, Protonix, or Pepcid), as these medications can cause stomach irritation. Make sure to take your steroid medication with meals, or a glass of milk. -Clearance to drive and return to work will be addressed at your post-operative office visit. -Make sure to continue to use your incentive spirometer while at home.
target: Pt electively presented and underwent a suboccipital craniotomy and resection of a ___ ventricular tumor. Surgery was without complication and the patient tolerated it well. She was treated with a 7 day course of levofloxacin ending on the day of discharge, and prednisone 60 mg orally for five days, followed by a decrease to 40 mg daily. She was instructed to complete a slow prednisone taper over the next several weeks. Additionally, she was treated with albuterol and atrovent nebulizers every four hours, as well as benzonatate and guafenesin for symptomatic relief. At discharge her cough and shortness of breath were significantly improved, but still decreased from baseline. The patient's mental status remained clear and coherent throughout the hospitalization, and he was able to ambulate independently. Upon discharge, the patient was advised to continue taking moxifloxacin for 7 more days.

If the pain medication is too sedating take half the dose and notify your physician. * Pneumonia is a complication of rib fractures. In order to decrease your risk you must use your incentive spirometer 4 times every hour while awake. This will help expand the small airways in your lungs and assist in coughing up secretions that pool in the lungs. * You will be more comfortable if you use a cough pillow to hold against your chest and guard your rib cage while coughing and deep breathing. * Symptomatic relief with ice packs or heating pads for short periods may ease the pain. * Narcotic pain medication can cause constipation therefore you should take a stool softener twice daily and increase your fluid and fiber intake if possible. * Do NOT smoke * If your doctor allows, non-steroidal ___ drugs are very effective in controlling pain ( ie, Ibuprofen, Motrin, Advil, Aleve, Naprosyn) but they have their own set of side effects so make sure your doctor approves. * Return to the Emergency Room right away for any acute shortness of breath, increased pain or crackling sensation around your ribs (crepitus).
target: Mr. ___ is a ___ year old male, with a PMH significant for epilepsy who fell 15 ft w/ head strike and +LOC. His imaging upon admission showed left posterior scalp hematoma/abrasion, frontal scalp laceration, L1-4 transverse process fractures, left 11th rib fracture, and right inferior and superior pubic rami fracture. He was seen by the orthopedics service for his pubic rami fracture, who felt he did not need surgical intervention and weight-bearing as tolerated. He was transferred to the floor hemodynamically stable. His pain was controlled on oral analgesics. ___ were consulted and he was ambulating with crutches. On HD3, he was noted to be in respiratory distress with tachypnea, increased oxygen requirement, and tachycardia to the 160s. CXR, CTA, ABGs, and labs were ordered. He was transferred to the TSICU due to his acute hypoxia. He was weaned off the non-rebreather to hiflow oxygen and eventually nasal cannula. On HD4, he was transferred back to the floor. Patient recuperated well on the floor, he worked with physical therapy which recommended discharge to home. He was weaned off O2 and on ___ was found ready to head home. Patient was instructed regarding warning signs and discharge instructions, he was also instructed to continue his respiratory recovery at home using his IS. He will follow up with us in clinic.
generated_summary: A 60-year-old male presents with progressive shortness of breath over the past month, echocardiogram shows reduced ejection fraction, and he underwent a traumatic fall from 15 feet resulting in multiple fractures including a fractured left posterior eleventh rib, left transverse process, and nondisplaced fractures through the right inferior and superior pubic rami. The patient is admitted to the trauma service and undergoes imaging studies including a CT chest, abdomen/pelvis, and CTA chest. The patient's condition is monitored closely, and he is prescribed medications for pain, constipation, and other complications. The patient is discharged home under the supervision of a physician.

generated_summary: A 45-year-old woman with metastatic breast cancer presented with worsening back pain, diagnosed with thoracic spine fractures, and underwent palliative radiation therapy. She was admitted for IVIG infusion. The patient experienced IVIG infusion complications, including anaphylaxis, which led to hospitalization and discontinuation of the treatment. The patient was transferred to the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) for respiratory failure, and eventually developed severe restrictive and obstructive lung disease, consistent with worsening graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) of the lungs. The patient remained hospitalized until death.

He has been on amoxicillin and ciprofloxacin for presumed skin colonization as directed by Dr. ___ ___; this was changed based on other antibiotics needs. His GVHD has progressed after receiving various immunesuppressant agents. He was started on ruxolitinib, the Jak 2 inhibitor for his GVHD on ___ as part of Protocol ___: Single patient IND of Ruxolitinib in a single patient, MA, with steroid refractory cGVHD. His dose has been adjusted over time, currently 15 mg following his HD, three times per week. He remains on Prednisone 10mg daily; Sirolimus has been discontinued. ___ other issues have been related to increasing shortness of breath requiring repeated admissions as outlined below. This has been in the setting of infections at times, but evaluation by Pulmonary has also shown worsening severe restrictive and obstructive lung disease, consistent with worsening GVHD of the lungs; this is related to sclerodermic GVHD of the chest wall causing restriction, plus possible bronchiolitis obliterans causing obstruction in the lung itself. He also has been noted for sCHF with reduced EF which contributes to his dyspnea, particularly in the setting of increased fluids. He has been followed by Dr. ___. He was on Torsemide for diuresis but often required IV Lasix when inpatient. ___ required a prolonged admission from ___ - ___ with initial issues of increasing cough, diarrhea, and shortness of breath. He was treated for acute on chronic mixed respiratory failure due to CHF exacerbation and pneumonia, acute renal failure, now with HD dependence on MWF hemodialysis schedule, and MRSA bacteremia (grown from port and HD line). Completed a 4-week course daptomycin with dapto locks. The HD line was ultimately replaced due to dehiscence of the tunneling. He developed an acute episode of respiratory distress requiring MICU admission; he was initiated on BiPAP with improvement in respiratory status, and he continues on this as an outpatient, using at night for the most part and during his dialysis. His renal failure was felt to be multi-factorial in the setting of aggressive diuresis for CHF and later with severe infection and sepsis. This was complicated by uremia/toxic-metabolic encephalopathy. He has not needed further diuretics since starting on HD and his most recent echo on ___ with LVEF of 45-50%. His breathing has been better overall with the dialysis but remains tenuous. He has continued on Pulmicort two puffs twice per day, azithromycin and montelukast. Recent PFT's showed a decrease further in his DLCO with stable Chest CT. PAST MEDICAL HISTORY/ONCOLOGIC HISTORY: * AML -Diagnosed in ___ after having a sore throat, cough and fever. Initially treated with ___ 7+3 regimen with a course complicated by fevers, sinusitis requiring multiple antibiotics, febrile neutropenia, s/p bronchoscopy (all cultures negative), C.Diff colitis, and retinal hemorrhage (from coughing). -Bone marrow biopsy on ___, without remission -Reinduction with MEC. Repeat bone marrow biopsy on day 14 after MEC did not show blasts. -MUD PSCT. Day ___: noted to have 10% peripheral blasts suggestive of clinical relapse; received chemotherapy and then DLI on ___, and remains in remission * Renal failure due to CHF is ongoing. _ is undergoing treatment with _____. **NOTE: All patients are patients of ___** <AGE> 65 years.  <Socioeconomic status> S1 (low income, limited access to healthcare) <Family background> ___ is supportive, but they are concerned about his prognosis. <Social Support> ___ is a supportive person who has been his primary care doctor.  <Lifestyle> _ engages in regular exercise and maintains a healthy diet.

**Question: What is the most likely reason for the patient's recent shortness of breath?**

**Answer:** The patient's recent shortness of breath is most likely related to worsening severe restrictive and obstructive lung disease due to sclerodermic

generated_summary: A 60-year-old male with a history of hypertension and diabetes presents with progressive shortness of breath over the past month. He was found to have a reduced ejection fraction on echocardiogram, and his symptoms worsened despite initial treatment with diuretics and beta-blockers. His laboratory results indicate elevated creatinine levels, indicating kidney dysfunction. His history includes a long-standing history of HIV/AIDS and multiple opportunistic infections, including PCP, MAC, and HCV. The patient is now experiencing worsening back pain and is admitted to the hospital for further evaluation and management.

target: Safety: Patient was placed on 15 minute checks on admission to unit. There were no safety issues during the hospitalization. Legal: ___ Psychiatric: ___ yoM with hx of MDD (no previous hospitalizations and no SA) and chronic nausea presents with SI and plan to poison self with CO after presenting to his outpatient ECT appointment. On exam patient has psychomotor retardation, a dysphoric affect and states that his mood is depressed. His admission labs were wnl and his chronic nausea has been extensively worked up without finding a source. It is possible that patient's nausea is a somatic delusion, especially with a negative extensive medical workup. Differential is depressive psychosis vs delusional do. Patient was continued on his home medications of clonazepam (1mg in AM and 0.5 in afternoon) and phenelzine 45mg BID. Ziprazodone was discontinued and 5mg of aripiprazole was started on ___. Aripiprazole was titrated to a dose of 7.5 on discharge and he tolerated it without side effects. Dr. ___ team was contacted and patient recieved ECT on ___, and ___ without reported side effects. Medical: #Chronic nausea- No acute issues, still with chronic nausea slightly improved with ECT. Continued home Prilosec 20 mg bid and Zantac 300 mg qhs. He was also given Zofran ODT 4mg bid PRN for nausea, although this did not help. #BPH- continued pt's home meds: tamsulosin 0.4 bid, Avodart 0.5 mg daily Collateral: Spoke with outpatient psychiatrist, Dr. ___. Dr. ___ has been treating patient since ___. Patient frequently makes SI comments that he wants to die because of his intractable nausea. However, patient has never acted on these urges/comments or been psychiatrically hospitalized. Psychiatrist says that he believes patient's nausea is associated with his depression. The nausea has been extensively worked up in past, both by gastroenterology and PCP, and has never revealed any pathology. Dr. ___ that nausea may be a manifestation of psychotic depression, and this is why he referred patient for ECT. Dr. ___ that patient has cluster A traits such as becoming paranoid and he never speaks of friends/family. Dr. ___ that he would prefer Mr. ___ to engage in psychotherapy as well as continuing to see to Dr. ___ psychiatric follow up. Spoke with PCP, ___. PCP relates that patient is relatively new to her. He has previously been extensively worked up in past for nausea ___ years. He had celiac/ h pylori workup that was negative. He has had both colonoscopy and EGD (___ last year) that was nonremarkable, but with a slight hiatial hernia. She has tried zantac/prilosec on him, but these do not seem to help. PCP has also done abdominal MRI, that did not reveal any pathology. She was considering referring him to GI again for furthur workup. PCP agrees that nausea seems linked with depression. PCP also said that in past patient has endorsed suicidal ideation, but he would say he had no intent to kill himself and he never had a plan. Risk Assessment: Patient is at moderate chronic risk of harm to self. Pt has no prior hospitalizations, SAs, family history of SA, no hx of impulsivity or substance use, and is help seeking. However, pt is also an unmarried white, elderly male living alone, has questionable reality testing ability, has frequent SI related to his intolerable and intractable nausea (and has hopelessness and anxiety regarding this), and has the means to act on his plan. It was reassuring to hear from the patient's psychiatrist and PCP, both say that patient's SI is a recurrent problem that is not new, suggesting that patient is at an elevated chronic risk to self, but his imminent risk is low/unchanged. While on Deaconness 4 patient's risk factors were modified by ECT therapy and change to aripiprazole for better cotnrol of both mood and delusions. He was encouraged to participate in outpatient psychotherapy. He reports that if he begins to feel worse he will go to the ___ 1 mile from his house.

He is started on diuretics and beta-blockers, and cardiology team plans for close outpatient follow-up. The patient's nausea is described as severe and debilitating, and he reports that he has been experiencing it for several months. He denies any previous episodes of nausea and is concerned that it may be related to his depression. He is currently being treated with ECT and has a significant somatic focus primarily on nausea, which he associates with his depression. The patient's mental status is clear and coherent, and he appears alert and interactive. He is ambulatory and independent, and his activity level is normal. The discharge diagnosis is major depression with delusion, and the condition is considered stable. The patient is advised to follow up with all outpatient appointments as scheduled and to continue taking all prescribed medications as directed. He

generated_summary: A 60-year-old male with a history of hypertension and diabetes presents with progressive shortness of breath over the past month. Echocardiogram shows reduced ejection fraction. He underwent treatment for cardiac conditions and was discharged home with a pacemaker. Upon admission, he developed chest pain and shortness of breath. Initial blood work showed elevated troponin levels and low hemoglobin. His electrocardiogram showed a new arrhythmia. Further testing revealed severe peripheral artery disease and gangrene in the right great toe. The patient was diagnosed with non-traumatic gangrene and underwent amputation of the affected toe. He was placed on warfarin and aspirin for anticoagulation and antiplatelet therapy respectively.

You should avoid contact sports for 6 months. Medications -Please do NOT take any blood thinning medication (Aspirin, Ibuprofen, Plavix, Coumadin) until cleared by the neurosurgeon. - You have been discharged on Keppra (Levetiracetam). This medication helps to prevent seizures. Please continue this medication as indicated on your discharge instruction. It is important that you take this medication consistently and on time. -You may use Acetaminophen (Tylenol) for minor discomfort if you are not otherwise restricted from taking this medication. What You ___ Experience: -You may have difficulty paying attention, concentrating, and remembering new information. -Emotional and/or behavioral difficulties are common. -Feeling more tired, restlessness, irritability, and mood swings are also common. -Constipation is common. Be sure to drink plenty of fluids and eat a high-fiber diet. If you are taking narcotics (prescription pain medications), try an over-the-counter stool softener. Headaches: -Headache is one of the most common symptom after a brain bleed. -Most headaches are not dangerous but you should call your doctor if the headache gets worse, develop arm or leg weakness, increased sleepiness, and/or have nausea or vomiting with a headache. -Mild pain medications may be helpful with these headaches but avoid taking pain medications on a daily basis unless prescribed by your doctor. -There are other things that can be done to help with your headaches: avoid caffeine, get enough sleep, daily exercise, relaxation/ meditation, massage, acupuncture, heat or ice packs. When to Call Your Doctor at ___ for: -Severe pain, swelling, redness or drainage from the incision site. -Fever greater than 101.5 degrees Fahrenheit -Nausea and/or vomiting -Extreme sleepiness and not being able to stay awake -Severe headaches not relieved by pain relievers -Seizures -Any new problems with your vision or ability to speak -Weakness or changes in sensation in your face, arms, or leg Call ___ and go to the nearest Emergency Room if you experience any of the following: -Sudden numbness or weakness in the face, arm, or leg -Sudden confusion or trouble speaking or understanding -Sudden trouble walking, dizziness, or loss of balance or coordination -Sudden severe headaches with no known reason

generated_summary: A 60-year-old male with a history of hypertension and diabetes presents with progressive shortness of breath over the past month. Echocardiogram shows reduced ejection fraction. He is started on diuretics and beta-blockers. Cardiology team plans for close outpatient follow-up. His current chief complaint is left-sided tremor and generalized weakness. The patient has a history of Afib on coumadin and small bowel lymphoma dx. Neurosurgery consult is sought due to concerns about bilateral mixed-density SDH. Initial imaging reveals predominantly hypodense mixed-density bilateral acute-on-chronic subdural hematomas. The patient's non-contracted head CT impression is similar to bilateral acute-on-chronic subdural hematomas. The patient is advised to return to the hospital for further evaluation and treatment.

Please follow the instructions below to continue your recovery: MEDICATION: - Take Aspirin 325mg (enteric coated) once daily - If instructed, take Plavix (Clopidogrel) 75mg once daily - Continue all other medications ___ were taking before surgery, unless otherwise directed - ___ make take Tylenol or prescribed pain medications for any post procedure pain or discomfort WHAT TO EXPECT: It is normal to have slight swelling of the legs: - Elevate your leg above the level of your heart with pillows every ___ hours throughout the day and night - Avoid prolonged periods of standing or sitting without your legs elevated - It is normal to feel tired and have a decreased appetite, your appetite will return with time - Drink plenty of fluids and eat small frequent meals - It is important to eat nutritious food options (high fiber, lean meats, vegetables/fruits, low fat, low cholesterol) to maintain your strength and assist in wound healing - To avoid constipation: eat a high fiber diet and use stool softener while taking pain medication ACTIVITIES: - When ___ go home, ___ may walk and use stairs - ___ may shower (let the soapy water run over groin incision, rinse and pat dry) - Your incision may be left uncovered, unless ___ have small amounts of drainage from the wound, then place a dry dressing or band aid over the area - No heavy lifting, pushing or pulling (greater than 5 lbs) for 1 week (to allow groin puncture to heal) - After 1 week, ___ may resume sexual activity - After 1 week, gradually increase your activities and distance walked as ___ can tolerate - No driving until ___ are no longer taking pain medications CALL THE OFFICE FOR: ___ - Numbness, coldness or pain in lower extremities - Temperature greater than 101.5F for 24 hours - New or increased drainage from incision or white, yellow or green drainage from incisions - Bleeding from groin puncture site SUDDEN, SEVERE BLEEDING OR SWELLING (Groin puncture site) - Lie down, keep leg straight and have someone apply firm pressure to area for 10 minutes. If bleeding stops, call vascular office ___. If bleeding does not stop, call ___ for transfer to closest Emergency Room. AMPUTATION DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS ACTIVITY: - On the side of your amputation ___ are non weight bearing for ___ weeks. - ___ should keep this amputation site elevated when ever possible. - ___ may use the opposite foot for transfers and pivots. - No driving until cleared by your Surgeon. - No heavy lifting greater than 20 pounds for the next 3 weeks. BATHING/SHOWERING: - ___ may shower when ___ get home - No tub baths or pools / do not soak your foot for 4 weeks from your date of surgery WOUND CARE: - Sutures / Staples may have been removed before discharge. If they are not, an appointment will be made for ___ to return for staple removal. - When the sutures are removed the doctor may or may not place pieces of tape called steri-strips over the incision. These will stay on about a week and ___ may shower with them on. If these do not fall off after 10 days, ___ may peel them off with warm water and soap in the shower. CAUTIONS: - If ___ smoke, please make every attempt to quit. Your primary care physician can help with this. Smoking causes narrowing of your blood vessels which in turn decreases circulation. DIET: - Low fat, low cholesterol / if ___ are diabetic Â– follow your dietary restrictions as before CALL THE OFFICE FOR: ___ - Bleeding, redness of, or drainage from your foot wound - New pain, numbness or discoloration of the skin on the effected foot - Fever greater than 101 degrees, chills, increased redness, or pus draining from the incision site. Weigh yourself every morning, call MD if weight goes up more than 3 lbs.

generated_summary: A 60-year-old man with a history of hypertension and diabetes presented with progressive shortness of breath over the past month. His echocardiogram showed reduced ejection fraction, indicating left ventricular dysfunction. He underwent a percutaneous transluminal angioplasty (PTA) of the femoral popliteal artery and proximal anastomosis, followed by a right lower extremity angiogram. The patient's symptoms worsened, and he developed peripheral vascular disease, a right foot ulcer, and acute pancreatitis. The patient was hospitalized for 10 days and underwent further surgical interventions, including carotid endarterectomy and right lower extremity bypass grafting. The patient is currently recovering from surgery and is ready to be discharged.

target: Mr. ___ is a ___ yo gentleman with history of oculobulbar myasthenia, on prednisone and recently added on azathioprine, who presented with one day of worsening shortness of breath ___ setting of one month of progressively worsening dysarthria, dysphagia, ptosis, and diplopia. The precipitating cause for this was unclear, but the subacute decline despite uptitration of immunosuppressive medications was concerning and the patient was admitted to the Neurology ICU. # Myasthenia Crisis The patient's exam showed significant bulbar and proximal weakness over the course of many days and required intubation shortly after admission to the hospital. He underwent plasmapheresis x 5 sessions (___). Neuromuscular specialists were consulted for treatment recommendations, with the following changes: azathioprine 200 mg daily, prednisone 60 mg daily, stop mestinon. TPMT activity normal, CT chest negative for thymoma, per outpatient neurologist. . Patient was initially NPO because of significant bulbar weaknees, with NS @ 75cc/hr. Once the patient was intubated, an OG was placed and TF were started. After extubation, he was evaluated by speech and swallow and passed - able to tolerate a regular diet which he will continue after discharge. . Physical therapy also worked with the patient and felt that he had no deficits after several inpatient ___ deficits and was safe for home discharge. . # Pulmonary - Respiratory failure, mixed Patient was intubated on ___ due to respiratory muscle fatigue, increasing O2 requirement, and increasing hypercarbia. He had increased secretion despite discontinuing mestinon. There was concern for aspiration pneumonitis causing elevated WBC but CXR was negative for aspiration or atelectasis. The patient had yellow mucoid secretions and was monitored closely for pneumonia. BAL showed no growth. Antibiotics were given for several days and then were discontinued. . # ID The patient was febrile to 100.8 on ___. Respiratory and urine cx were sent and returned negative. Empiric Abx with vanc/cefepime were started but DCed once culures returned negative. . # Blood pressure Patient was on continuous telemetry monitoring, with no acute events. Lisinopril was initially continued on admission but then held because of soft pressures after intubation; he was on low dose phenylephrine while on propofol, but the pressor was weaned off after 3 days. He was resumed on his lisinopril on discharge. . # Endocrine Home metformin was held due to need for multiple medication changes and tests that could affect renal function. The patient was treated with insulin SS. Metformin was reinstated and tolerated well prior to discharge. . # TRANSITIONAL ISSUES # - Increased prednisone to 60mg daily - Increased azathioprine to 200mg daily - Stopped Mestinon
generated_summary: A 45-year-old woman with metastatic breast cancer presents with worsening back pain, neurological symptoms such as shortness of breath, dysarthria, and dysphagia, which are thought to be related to her myasthenia gravis. She underwent palliative radiation therapy, and then received chemotherapy and immunotherapy. After receiving several courses of plasmapheresis, she began to show improvement. Her symptoms have since worsened, indicating a potential relapse.

Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker or cane). <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> You were admitted to the hospital after a Laparoscopic Proctocolectomy With End Ileostomy for surgical management of your Ulcerative Colitis. You have recovered from this procedure well and you are now ready to return home. Samples from your colon were taken and this tissue has been sent to the pathology department for analysis. You will receive these pathology results at your follow-up appointment. If there is an urgent need for the surgeon to contact you regarding these results they will contact you before this time. You have tolerated a regular diet, are passing gas and your pain is controlled with pain medications by mouth. You may return home to finish your recovery. Please monitor your bowel function closely. You may or may not have had a bowel movement prior to your discharge which is acceptable, however it is important that you have a bowel movement in the next ___ days. After anesthesia it is not uncommon for patientÂ’s to have some decrease in bowel function but you should not have prolonged constipation. Some loose stool and passing of small amounts of dark, old appearing blood are expected. However, if you notice that you are passing bright red blood with bowel movements or having loose stool without improvement please call the office or go to the emergency room if the symptoms are severe. If you are taking narcotic pain medications there is a risk that you will have some constipation. Please take an over the counter stool softener such as Colace, and if the symptoms do not improve call the office. If you have any of the following symptoms please call the office for advice or go to the emergency room if severe: increasing abdominal distension, increasing abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, inability to tolerate food or liquids, prolonged loose stool, or extended constipation. You have ___ laparoscopic surgical incisions on your abdomen which are closed with internal sutures and a skin glue called Dermabond. These are healing well however it is important that you monitor these areas for signs and symptoms of infection including: increasing redness of the incision lines, white/green/yellow/malodorous drainage, increased pain at the incision, increased warmth of the skin at the incision, or swelling of the area. Please call the office if you develop any of these symptoms or a fever. You may go to the emergency room if your symptoms are severe. You may shower; pat the incisions dry with a towel, do not rub. The small incisions may be left open to the air. If closed with steri-strips (little white adhesive strips) instead of Dermabond, these will fall off over time, please do not remove them. Please no baths or swimming for 6 weeks after surgery unless told otherwise by Dr. ___ Dr. ___. You will be prescribed a small amount of the pain medication oxycodone. Please take this medication exactly as prescribed. You may take Tylenol as recommended for pain. Please do not take more than 4000mg of Tylenol daily. Do not drink alcohol while taking narcotic pain medication or Tylenol. Please do not drive a car while taking narcotic pain medication. No heavy lifting greater than 6 lbs for until your first post-operative visit after surgery. Please no strenuous activity until this time unless instructed otherwise by Dr. ___ Dr. ___. Thank you for allowing us to participate in your care! Our hope is that you will have a quick return to your life and usual activities. Good luck!
target: ___ F past medical history of atrial fibrillation on rivaroxaban, latent TB on INH, ulcerative colitis, presented with non-focal weakness and diarrhea. # Diarrhea: Loose, occasionally bloody stools without mucus and associated abdominal pain but no upper GI symptoms. GI was consulted, and the case was staffed with her outpatient gastroenterologist. She had negative stool cultures. She underwent a flexible sigmoidoscopy, the findings of which were consistent with active ulcerative colitis (pathology similarly consistent with UC). CT scan showed colonic inflammation to the splenic flexure, consistent with a UC flare. Colorectal was consulted, with plan for surgery. She underwent a laparoscopic proctocolectomy with end ileostomy on ___. She tolerated the procedure well with no complications and was transferred to the PACU in stable condition. Please see the operative note for technical details. Postop, her pain was initially controlled with a dilaudid PCA then she was switched to oral pain meds. Her diet was initially advanced to clears on POD#1 but he became nauseous from this was was made NPO again. She was then advanced slowly till she was tolerating a regular diet. On POD#7, she c/o urinary urgency and a UA showed large luekocytes so she was given ceftriaxone for one day then switched to 3 day course of ciprofloxacin. The days afterwards were spent encouraging her to increase her PO intake, working with a dietician and continuing TPN. By POD#11, she was ambulating with assistance, tolerating regular diet and her pain was controlled with oral pain meds so she was deemd fit for discharge to a rehab facility. # Hypokalemia: Ongoing hypokalemia associated with continued diarrhea. She was repleted twice to three times daily while being monitored on telemetry. # Weakness: Nonfocal neurologic exam throughout with negative head CT and no signs or symptoms of sepsis. Most likely due to deconditioning and ongoing diarrheal losses. Patient refused to work with Physical Therapy while on the ___ but was willing to ambulate and get OOB after surgery. Her nutrition was supplemented with Ensure and she was started on TPN postop. She was also given Megace to help stimulate her appetite; calorie counts were ordered and she was seen by a dietician to advice her on the best types of foods to consume to maximize caloric intake. # Acute on Chronic Anemia: Likely having small GI losses from her ulcerative colitis with low iron stores from poor nutrition. Because she is a Jehovah's Witness, she will not accept blood products; a signed acknowledgement of this was placed in her chart, and confirmed with her HCP/daughter. # Latent TB: Patient had been started on INH in preparation for starting Remicade; however, after biologic therapy was determined not to be an option for her, patient opted to discontinue her INH. # Atrial Fibrillation: CHADS-VASC of ___ with history of stroke putting her at high thromboembolic risk. Xarelto was stopped pre-operatively in favor of heparin gtt... Her home metoprolol was continued (except when held for low blood pressures responsive to IV fluids as above). Postop, heparin gtt was stopped and levenox was restarted. She was restarted on metoprolol to control her atrial fibrillation after surgery. She will restart Xarelto after discharge. # Glaucoma: Continued home dose eye drops. # Hypertension: Held home Norvasc given normotension (with occasional episodes of hypotension). Amlodipine restarted after surgery
generated_summary: A 45-year-old female with metastatic breast cancer presents with worsening back pain and imaging shows thoracic spine fractures. She undergoes flexible sigmoidoscopy and biopsy, which confirm the diagnosis of ulcerative colitis. She is treated with metoprolol tartrate, latanoprost, pantoprazole, rivaroxaban, and oxycodone. She is discharged home to continue her treatment and recovery.

input: <SEX> M <SERVICE> SURGERY <ALLERGIES> No Known Allergies / Adverse Drug Reactions <ATTENDING> ___. <CHIEF COMPLAINT> Aortic Abdominal Aneurysm <MAJOR SURGICAL OR INVASIVE PROCEDURE> Fenestrated endovascular aneurysm repair <HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS> HPI: Mr. ___ is a ___ year old male with a known AAA from over ___ years ago initially followed by his PCP with care now handed over to Dr. ___. The patient has had vascular abdominal ultrasounds every 6 months, and the last US showed that it was <5.5cm. However, he was most recently surveyed with a CTA, which showed that the AAA was 6.2cm in diameter. The patient has a history of sigmoid colectomy for diverticulitis c/b anastomotic breakdown requiring open abdomen and end colostomy. Due to his complicated abdominal anatomy, the patient was referred to Dr. ___ potential endovascular intervention. The patient has been asymptomatic. He denies chest pain, abdominal pain, back pain, fatigue in his thighs, claudication, rest pain, or "blue toe syndrome." The patient currently works approximately 5 hours a day. He is able to walk any distance and is able to climb stairs without having to stop. The patient is A current active smoker. He does report that he is attempting to quit smoking. <PAST MEDICAL HISTORY> PMH: HTN, arthritis, chronic back pain, diverticulitis <SOCIAL HISTORY> ___ <FAMILY HISTORY> FH: Mother - HLD, macular degeneration, HTN Father - MI, heart failure Brother - lung cancer <PHYSICAL EXAM> Vitals: 24 HR Data (last updated ___ @ 803) Temp: 98.8 (Tm 99.3), BP: 144/75 (103-144/58-77), HR: 93 (78-98), RR: 19 (___), O2 sat: 100% (94-100), O2 delivery: RA, Wt: 201.1 lb/91.22 kg GENERAL: [X]NAD [X]A/O x 3 []intubated/sedated []abnormal CV: []RRR [] irregularly irregular []no MRG []Nl S1S2 []abnormal PULM: []CTA b/l [X]no respiratory distress []abnormal ABD: []soft []Nontender []appropriately tender []nondistended []no rebound/guarding []abnormal WOUND: [X]CD&I []no erythema/induration []abnormal EXTREMITIES: []no CCE []abnormal PULSES: R: / /P/P/ L: / /P/P/ <PERTINENT RESULTS> ___ 07: 57PM GLUCOSE-143* UREA N-13 CREAT-0.9 SODIUM-140 POTASSIUM-4.4 CHLORIDE-105 TOTAL CO2-23 ANION GAP-12 ___ 07: 57PM estGFR-Using this ___ 07: 57PM CALCIUM-8.4 PHOSPHATE-3.8 MAGNESIUM-1.6 ___ 07: 57PM WBC-11.4* RBC-3.89* HGB-12.0* HCT-36.3* MCV-93 MCH-30.8 MCHC-33.1 RDW-13.2 RDWSD-45.1 ___ 07: 57PM PLT COUNT-147* ___ 07: 57PM ___ PTT-88.3* ___ <MEDICATIONS ON ADMISSION> Meclizine 20 mg as needed, lisinopril 20 mg daily, Lipitor 40 mg daily, Nexium 40 mg as needed, aspirin 81 mg daily, metoprolol XL 25 mg daily, multivitamin daily, vitamin B complex daily, vitamin C 500 mg daily, vitamin E 100 international unit daily, vitamin D ___ international units daily, fish oil 1200 mg daily, omega-3 360 mg daily <DISCHARGE MEDICATIONS> 1. Aspirin EC 81 mg PO DAILY 2. Atorvastatin 40 mg PO QPM 3. Lisinopril 20 mg PO DAILY 4. Metoprolol Succinate XL 25 mg PO DAILY 5. Pantoprazole 40 mg PO Q24H <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home With Service Facility: ___ <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> Aortic Abdominal Aneurysm <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> You were admitted to ___ and underwent endovascular aneurysm repair. You have now recovered from surgery and are ready to be discharged. Please follow the instructions below to continue your recovery: MEDICATIONS: - Take Aspirin 325mg (enteric coated) once daily - Do not stop Aspirin unless your Vascular Surgeon instructs you to do so. - Continue all other medications you were taking before surgery, unless otherwise directed - You make take Tylenol or prescribed pain medications for any post procedure pain or discomfort WHAT TO EXPECT AT HOME: It is normal to have slight swelling of the legs: - Elevate your leg above the level of your heart (use ___ pillows or a recliner) every ___ hours throughout the day and at night - Avoid prolonged periods of standing or sitting without your legs elevated It is normal to feel tired and have a decreased appetite, your appetite will return with time - Drink plenty of fluids and eat small frequent meals - It is important to eat nutritious food options (high fiber, lean meats, vegetables/fruits, low fat, low cholesterol) to maintain your strength and assist in wound healing - To avoid constipation: eat a high fiber diet and use stool softener while taking pain medication ACTIVITIES: - When you go home, you may walk and go up and down stairs - You may shower (let the soapy water run over groin incision, rinse and pat dry) - Your incision may be left uncovered, unless you have small amounts of drainage from the wound, then place a dry dressing or band aid over the area that is draining, as needed - No heavy lifting, pushing or pulling (greater than 5 lbs) for 1 week (to allow groin puncture to heal) - After 1 week, you may resume sexual activity - After 1 week, gradually increase your activities and distance walked as you can tolerate - No driving until you are no longer taking pain medications CALL THE OFFICE FOR: ___ - Numbness, coldness or pain in lower extremities - Temperature greater than 101.5F for 24 hours - New or increased drainage from incision or white, yellow or green drainage from incisions - Bleeding from groin puncture site FOR SUDDEN, SEVERE BLEEDING OR SWELLING (Groin puncture site or incision) - Lie down, keep leg straight and have someone apply firm pressure to area for 10 minutes. If bleeding stops, call vascular office. If bleeding does not stop, call ___ for transfer to closest Emergency Room.
target: Mr. ___ is a ___ year old male with AAA who was admitted to the ___ on ___. The patient was taken to the endovascular suite and underwent FEVAR. For details of the procedure, please see the surgeon's operative note. The patient tolerated the procedure well without complications and was brought to the post-anesthesia care unit in stable condition. After a brief stay, the patient was transferred to the ICU at which time the patients lumbar drain was capped, SBPs were controlled briefly on/off nitro and eventually off nitro. On POD#1 we obtained a CTA which was negative for an endoleak, the patient was on a regular diet, drain was capped and we decided that the patient should stay in the ICU overnight. On POD#2, the patients drain came out, we removed the patients foley, A-line and moved the patient to our VICU. On POD#3 the patient was ambulating well and ready for discharge home. Post-operatively, he did well without any groin swelling. He was able to tolerate a regular diet, get out of bed and ambulate without assistance, void without issues, and pain was controlled on oral medications alone. He was deemed ready for discharge, and was given the appropriate discharge and follow-up instructions.

target: Mr. ___ was admitted to the Transplant Surgery Service under Dr. ___ on ___ for pain control after a splenic artery embolization done by the Interventional Radiology service. He received PO Dilaudid and standing tylenol for pain control during his hospital stay. On the morning of ___, his Hct was 19.4, a repeat Hct was 18.6. He was given 2u pRBCs. A post-transfusion Hct was 22. He spiked to 102.7 for which he was pan-cultred. CXR was negative for pneumonia. IV Zosyn was started for empiric coverage. Right groin puncture site pain was persistent. U/S of the area identified a 2.5 cm partially thrombosed right groin pseudoaneurysm, with a neck measuring 3 mm in width. Hct decreased to 19 again. IV Vitamin K was given for INR of 2.9. An abdominal CT was also done demonstrating just ascites. Post CT, creatinine increased to 3.9. He was bloused with IV fluid for low urine output. ___ then embolized the pseudoaneurysm on ___. Postop, embolization, right groin appeared ecchymotic with positive distal pulses. He had less pain in the right groin. Hct was down to 17. Two units of PRBC were transfused with post hct of 23. Postop transfusion, he had an 8 beat run of VTach that resolved. Calcium repletion was given for calcium of 7.5. Hct stabilized at ___. LFTs were notable of rise in t.bili to 3.9. ERCP was done on to interrogate the metal stent on ___. It was noted that the previously placed metal stent had migrated, a CBD anastomotic stricture was noted and a new MS was placed. He tolerated this procedure well and diet was advanced to regular the next day. A repeat U/S of the groin was done on ___lood flow at the neck of the pseudoaneurysm which may represent a small arterial branch vessel. No documented flow within the body of the pseudoaneurysm. He continued to have discomfort at this site as well as abdominal and back pain for which he was receiving po Dilaudid. He was taking a total of ___ per day of the Dilaudid. The plan was to send him home with a script for dilaudid 2mg prn every 8 hours with only 10 tabs. Of note, the anemia/hemolysis w/u was negative. He received a total of 3 units of prbc. Leukopenia was improving. Blood and urine cultures were negative to date. Creatinine increased and this was likely related to the contrast given during the angiogram. Creatinine increased to 3.9, but had decreased to 3.0 on the day of discharge. Potassium was elevated to 5.4. He was instructed to follow a low potassium diet, have his labs checked on ___ and to resume the Florinef. Weight was 77kg up from admission weight of 71kg. Urine output was averaging 400cc/day. A repeat right groin U/S should be done one week from ___ to assess pseudoaneurysm. At time of discharge, vitals signs were stable, he was a regular diet, ambulating independently.
generated_summary: A 60-year-old male underwent emergency laparoscopic splenectomy for symptomatic splenomegaly. Postoperative pain management included hydrocortisone, albuterol inhaler, cyclosporine, metoprolol succinate, and vitamin D. Patients were advised to drink plenty of fluids and eat nutritious food options to support recovery. The patient's mental status remained clear and coherent throughout hospitalization. Upon discharge, patients were instructed to continue their current medications, including hydrocortisone, albuterol inhaler, cyclosporine, metoprolol succinate, and vitamin D, and to follow up with their surgeon and pharmacist for follow-up instructions. The patient's vital signs were monitored closely during the hospital stay. The patient's activities included walking and using stairs, but they avoided heavy lifting, pushing, or pulling for one week due to the groin puncture site. The patient was advised against numbness, coldness, or pain

generated_summary: A 45-year-old female patient with metastatic breast cancer underwent a cardiac catheterization procedure. The imaging study showed a triangular opacity in the right middle lung field, which was later confirmed as a pleural mass. Further imaging studies, including CT-guided pleural mass biopsy, were performed. The biopsy result showed a benign pleural mass, and the patient was discharged with a plan for follow-up care. The patient's symptoms worsened, prompting a return visit to the emergency department. The patient presented with worsening back pain, shortness of breath, and chest pain. The patient's laboratory results showed elevated creatinine levels, and the patient was diagnosed with a new diagnosis of aortic regurgitation. The patient was admitted to the intensive care unit for further management. The patient's condition improved, and the patient was eventually discharged.

target: Pt is ___ yo M with hx of of prior silent MI, HTN, HLD, transitional cell carcinoma (s/p radiation, no surgery or chemo) who p/w LLE edema and swelling . # DVT: Given the patient's history of bladder cancer and radiation within the past year, his LLE edema was most consistent on presentation with lymphatic obstruction, either from reseeding of the lymphatic bed with tumor or direct damage from radiation. However, the patient's pain on hip flexion, tenderness in the left hip, and acute onset suggested DVT. LENIs were negative, suggesting a more proximal DVT. He was started on a heparin drip on admission. CT abd/pelvis the following day demonstrated a 2cm DVT in the left external iliac vein. The patient's heparin drip was continued, and he was started on 5mg coumadin. His INR remained subtherapeutic, and his coumadin was increased to 10mg. The patient initially refused to go home on Lovenox injections on account of his fear of needles but after several attempts at counseling, he agreed to administer his own Lovenox with the assistance of a home ___ until his INR became therapeutic. He was discharged with 110mg BID Lovenox injections, 10mg coumadin qdaily, and scheduled to follow-up with his PCP to manage his anticoagulation over the next 6 months. He should follow-up with oncology or his PCP regarding how long to continue on anticoagulation given that inciting cause of DVT was either malignancy or XRT and it is unclear whether the provoking agent can ever be considered removed. . # Acute renal insufficiency: The patient's baseline Cr is 1.2 and was 1.3 on admission. Per the patient, he has been dehydrated the previous 2 days. His Cr remained at baseline after adequate IVF rehydration and was 1.2 upon discharge. . # Bladder CA - In-house CT abd/pelvis showed no evidence of recurrence or metastatic spread of patient's previous bladder cancer. The patient was scheduled for routine surveillance CT in ___, and we have communicated with his radiation oncologist in order to cancel this study, if the in-house CT performed during this hospitalization is sufficient to rule out recurrence. . # HTN - The patient's blood pressure was well-controlled throughout his hospitalization on his home anti-hypertensives. . # Hyperlipidemia - The patient was continued on his home statin. . # S/p silent MI - Given the patient's history of silent MI, we have communicated with the patient's PCP regarding aspirin and ACE inhibitor therapy. He will follow-up with his PCP for further management of this condition. .

The patient is discharged home after two days of hospitalization, where he will be followed up in a rehabilitation center to address his respiratory and cardiovascular issues.

target: ___ m with hx of HTN, DM II, BPH who presented with sudden onset fevers, chills, and rigors. Infectious work up concerning for possible retrocardiac pneumonia +/- influenza. Hospital course c/b rash on L leg and positive blood culture. ACTIVE ISSUES: # Fevers: Most likely secondary to a viral process. Patient had defervesced on arrival, but had one low-grade fever on HOD #3. Initially, he was treated empirically with Tamiflu for suspected influenza infection. After his DFA returned negative for flu on HOD #4, Tamiflu was discontinued. One blood culture from HOD #3 return positive for coagulase negative staph, but as all other blood cultures from this admission were negative, and patient was hemodynamically stable, this was most likely a contaminant. Additionally, he was noted to have a patchy erythematous rash on his left lower leg on HOD #3. Thus, he was started on vancomycin empirically for coverage of cellulitis. He continued vancomycin ___ at discharge; at that time, he was transitioned to cephalexin to complete a 7-day course of antibiotics for cellulitis. Although rash appeared atypical for cellulitis, it seemed to improve with antibiotics. ACE wraps were applied to legs, and legs were elevated, as patient reported similar afflication with venous stasis in the past. # Bacteremia: One blood culture from ___ grew coagulase-negative staph. Although this was likely just a contaminant (blood cultures from ___ and ___ without growth, it was covered by empiric antibiotics, as above. Patient will finish 7-day course of cephalexin as an outpatient. # LLE Rash / cellulitis: Unilateral, with patchy erythema that appeared atypical for cellulitis. LLE ultrasound was negative for DVT. In the setting of fevers, empiric vancomycin was started on ___ for coverage, and rash appeared to improve. Patient to complete 7-day course with cephalexin after discharge. ACE wraps were applied to legs, and legs were elevated, as patient reported similar afflication with venous stasis in the past. He was instructed to use compression stockings at home. His ultrasound did show an enlarged lymph node on the left side, c/w an underlying infectious/inflammatory process. CHRONIC ISSUES: #HTN: Stable. Continued on home regimen. #BPH: Patient denied any recent urinary retention or hesitancy. Prostate exam normal. He continued his home finesteride and doxazosin. TRANSITIONAL ISSUES: # Follow up finalized blood cultures from ___ and ___. # Consider repeat imaging if left inguinal LAD persists # Full code: confirmed
generated_summary: A 60-year-old man with a history of hypertension, diabetes, and type 2 diabetes presents with progressive shortness of breath over the past month. He is diagnosed with influenza A and B, and urinary tract infections (UTIs), including a possible staph infection. He is prescribed doxazosin, finasteride, levemfolate-B6, phos-methyl-B12, cephalexin, docusate sodium, polyethylene glycol, senna, and antibiotics for treatment of UTI and possibly staph infection. Follow-up appointments include a visit to his primary care physician after discharge.

target: SUMMARY STATEMENT ================= Ms. ___ is a ___ year-old woman with a history of severe peripheral vascular disease s/p left AKA and R bypass c/b graft and popliteal artery stenosis s/p multiple angioplasties, DM, and secondary adrenal insufficiency, presenting with polymicrobial R heel infection s/p debridement x2, with wound vac and on IV vanc/cefepime/flagyl for 6 week course per ID recommendation. ACUTE ISSUES ADDRESSED: ===================== #Polymicrobial R heel osteomyelitis, R heel ulcer infection History of T2DM and severe PVD s/p R bypass with multiple angioplasties, chronic right heel ulcer, presented with heel ulcer drainage, pain and erythema. She underwent OR I&D/debridement x2 (___) with Podiatry. Operative debridement yielded deep purulence down to the calcaneus. Due to the chronicity of the ulcer and the proximity of the purulence so close to calcaneus, decision made to treat for osteomyelitis. Vascular surgery was consulted and said there was no need for intervention. Wound cultures grew two morphologies of e. coli (which had no clear PO options for treatment based on sensitivities, but were susceptible to CTX), b frag, and coag neg staph sensitive to clinda/vanc. No pseudomonas. Blood cx no growth. Infectious Disease team was consulted and recommended cefepime, vancomycin, and metronidazole given possibility of pseudonomonas ___ diabetic patient, even if not grown on culture. Antibiotic course planned for 6 weeks from last instrumentation ___, therefore finishing ___. She was cleared by Physical Therapy for home. She will follow-up with podiatry, vascular, and ID. Her daughter ___ was trained on taking care of the wound vac at home (per Podiatry, anticipate several weeks) and home antibiotic administration. She will have weekly labs checked. #Revision of diagnosis: No secondary adrenal insufficiency During last hospitalization, as part of workup for hyponatremia, she was thought to have secondary adrenal insufficiency. The etiology was not elucidated, however, she was started on hydrocortisone 10 mg QAM. Given active infection and surgery this admission, she received stress dose steroids with a taper. Following this, the ID team noted a positive quantiferon gold that had resulted from the last admission. Endocrine was reconsulted to further investigate the AI diagnosis as patient might require latent TB treatment if planning for chronic steroids. On repeat ___ stim testing, pt had appropriate and robust response, making adrenal insufficiency unlikely. MRI adrenal protocol was within normal limits. ACTH levels were normal. Patient no longer though to have AI. #Hyponatremia #?SIADH Worked up extensively last admission and felt to be due to secondary adrenal insufficiency with possible SIADH. This admission, adrenal insufficiency workup was again pursued and it was determined patient does not have this. Steroids were discontinued, pressures were maintained, and there was no ill effect. Several days later, patient's sodium downtrended. Urine studies consistent with SIADH so patient placed on fluid restriction of 1.5 liters. Her sodium levels fluctuated but ultimately stable and near normal limits. #Diabetes Mellitus, type 2 On admission, held home metformin 500mg PO BID, continued home lantus 10 units QHS, and provided insulin sliding scale. Elevated blood sugars ___ the setting of stress-dose steroids, were covered with NPH, subsequently discontinued. On ___, metformin 500mg BID was restarted as patient awaiting placement. #Hypertension Patient's blood pressures were elevated and lisinopril was uptitrated from 10mg to 40mg with good results. # Anemia Underlying Iron deficiency anemia and anemia of chronic disease. Hgb 9.1 on admission. Received 2U pRBC following surgeries. Patient was given IV ferrous gluconate for 4 days. Stable rest of admission. CHRONIC ISSUES ADDRESSED: ======================= #Type 4 RTA Diagnosed last admission and thought ___ diabetes. Continued on sodium bicarbonate. #Latent TB Quant gold+. No pulmonary sx, CXR unconcerning, and adrenals within normal limits on CT. Pt is at moderate risk for reactivation given insulin-dependent diabetes, though does not have adrenal insufficiency and so will not receive further steroids. ___ consultation with ID, treatment of latent TB was deferred. # Peripheral vascular disease History of severe peripheral vascular disease s/p left AKA and R bypass c/b graft and popliteal artery stenosis s/p multiple angioplasties. Chronic R non-healing ulcer ___ setting of T2DM and severe PVD. This admission she had noninvasive RLE arterial study which showed severe obstructive arterial disease. Vascular surgery was consulted and said that no intervention was indicated. Continued home ASA, atorvastatin, clopidogrel; stopped home cilostazol --for claudication, patient not ambulatory, and wanted to reduce pill burden and risk of side effects. TRANSITIONAL ISSUES: ================== [] f/u antihypertensive regimen [] f/u DM regimen [] please ensure family is comfortable with wound vac management. Training was done before discharge. OPAT Diagnosis: R foot diabetic foot ulcer c/b osteomyelitis OPAT Antimicrobial Regimen and Projected Duration: Agent & Dose: Vancomycin 1 gram q 24hours (pending new trough- dose adjusted ___ + Cefepime 2 grams q24hours + Flagyl 500mg PO q 8 hours Start Date: ___ (date of last debridement ___ Projected End Date: ___ LAB MONITORING RECOMMENDATIONS: NOTE: For lab work to be drawn after discharge, a specific standing order for Outpatient Lab Work is required to be placed ___ the Discharge Worksheet - Post-Discharge Orders. Please place an order for Outpatient Labs based on the MEDICATION SPECIFIC GUIDELINE listed below: ALL LAB RESULTS SHOULD BE SENT TO: ATTN: ___ CLINIC - FAX: ___ WEEKLY: CBC with differential, BUN, Cr, Vancomycin trough *PLEASE ALSO OBTAIN WEEKLY CRP Health care proxy: ___ Relationship: daughter Phone number: ___ FULL CODE
generated_summary: A 45-year-old female underwent emergency surgery to remove a malignant tumor from her chest. She developed a complicated wound infection of the right foot, which became resistant to treatment. Her adrenal glands were initially thought to be affected but were later confirmed to be functioning normally. She received extensive medical and surgical interventions, including chemotherapy, radiation therapy, and surgery. The patient's condition improved significantly, and she was eventually able to discontinue her steroids and receive palliative care.

TECHNIQUE: Multiplanar T1- and T2-weighted imaging of the head was performed without and with IV contrast. FINDINGS: There is a large heterogeneous mass lesion, in the right temporoparietal lobes, with areas of hemorrhage, cystic change, necrosis and large solid enhancing component. The solid competent measures 5.0 x 4.3 cm. There is entrapment of the right temporal horn. There is surrounding significant vasogenic edema, with a leftward shift of subfalcine herniation; measuring approximately 1 cm is unchanged, allowing for technical differences, compared to the prior CT. Mass effect on the right lateral ventricle, is unchanged. There is a 1.7 x 1.6 cm round focus of increased signal on the FLAIR, with enhancement on the post-contrast images in the left parapharyngeal space, which corresponds to an abnormally enlarged lymph node, on correlation with the CT angiogram performed on the same day (series 9, image 1), however, this is not completely included on our present study. IMPRESSION: 1. Large heterogeneous mass lesion in the right parietal and temporal lobes, with cystic, necrotic, hemorrhagic and solid components, the solid competent measuring 5.0 cm, with significant surrounding edema, mass effect and subfalcine herniation, and entrapment of the right temporal horn without significant change since the CT head done the day before. 2. 1.7-cm enhancing focus in the left parapharyngeal region, representing an abnormally enlarged lymph node, representing metastatic involvement. However, this is not completely included on our present study. MR HEAD W & W/O CONTRAST ___ 2: 41 ___ MR HEAD W & W/O CONTRAST Reason: residual mass? Contrast: MAGNEVIST UNDERLYING MEDICAL CONDITION: ___ year old man with parietal mass s/p resection REASON FOR THIS EXAMINATION: residual mass? CONTRAINDICATIONS for IV CONTRAST: None. GADOLINIUM-ENHANCED MR SCAN OF THE BRAIN HISTORY: Status post resection of right parietal mass. Assess for residual tumor. TECHNIQUE: Multiplanar T1- and T2-weighted brain imaging was obtained pre- and post-gadolinium administration. COMPARISON STUDY: MR scan of the brain from ___. FINDINGS: There is a lace-like pattern of enhancement along the anteromedial aspect of the right temporal lobe, apparently surrounding the right temporal horn body. There is persistent mild dilatation of the right temporal horn tip, but substantially reduced in extent compared to the prior preoperative study. Additionally, there is presumed hemorrhage along the operative tract, more peripherally situated within the posterior aspect of the right temporal lobe. The extensive edema surrounding the formerly very large tumor appears unaltered in extent. However, overall, there is somewhat less mass effect, though there is still leftward subfalcine herniation present. Numerous tiny areas of elevated T2 signal are seen within the white matter of both cerebral hemispheres, presumably representing chronic small vessel infarctions or post- inflammatory residua. There is soft tissue swelling, subgaleal in locale at the craniotomy site and there is a possible fluid collection or surgical material within the crescent- shaped space between the dura spanning the craniotomy flap and the inner table of the flap itself. There is redemonstration of the well- defined, rounded 21 mm area of contrast enhancement in the left parapharyngeal fat area. Its sharp margination seems most consistent with a benign neoplastic process (question neurogenic tumor). This location would be very unusual for a lymph node or metastatic disease, as was suggested on the previous report. CONCLUSION: Findings suggest that there is residual tumor in the region of the right temporal lobe surrounding the right temporal horn, with mild residual entrapment of this portion of the right lateral ventricle, as described above. target: The patient was admitted to the neurosurgery service with an intraventricular mass in the ICU for close monitoring. He was started on Decadron and dilantin. An MRI was obtained to further characterize the lesion. A staging CT of the torso was obtained which showed metastasis to the lungs, left hilum, and spine. He was hydrated with bicarb fluids and given Mucomyst for renal protection prior to the CT scans. On HD#2 he was transferred to the neuro step down unit. A WAND study was obtained for image guidance of the resection. He was taken to the OR for resection of the brain mass on HD#5. He tolerated the procedure well and initially recovered in the PACU. He was extubated in the PACU without difficulty. He was then transferred to the neurosurgery step down unit. On POD#1 a repeat MRI was obtained which showed no bleeding. He was then transferred to the floor. On POD#2 his diet was advanced, his Foley was removed and he was seen by ___. His Decadron was weaned to 2 mg TID. He was seen by oncology and radiation oncology who recommended follow up in the brain tumor clinic and the ___ clinic. These appointments were set up for the patient. His antibiotics were stopped on POD#4. On POD#5 he was tolerating a regular diet, he had had a bowel movement, he was voiding without difficulty and he was cleared by ___ for home. He was discharged home with follow up instructions.
generated_summary: A 61-year-old male underwent a right parietal resection for a primary tumor. After surgery, he developed a persistent, large heterogenous mass lesion in the right temporal lobe, with cystic, necrotic, hemorrhagic, and solid components. The mass is located near the right temporal horn and shows mild residual entrapment of the right lateral ventricle. The pathology pending indicates that the mass is likely a neurogenic tumor. The patient's condition is stable, and he is expected to recover fully with appropriate treatment and follow-up care.

target: She was admitted to the surgery service. She underwent CT abdomen and pelvis that showed dilated CBD with possible stone lodged at ampulla. She was transferred to the ICU and underwent an ERCP. A PICC line was placed for IV antibiotics. The ERCP showed multiple stones and sludge at the biliary tree extracted successfully (sphincterotomy, stone extraction, stent placement). Patient transferred out of ICU to a regular floor. She has continued to progress and is tolerating a regular diet, pain controlled and ambulating independently. She will be discharged to home on Cipro 500 mg BID to continue for 7 more days.
generated_summary: A 60-year-old male with a history of hypertension and diabetes presents with progressive shortness of breath over the past month. He undergoes echocardiogram showing dilated left ventricular end-diastolic volume (LVEDV) and LVEDV/LVEDV ratio > 1.2, indicating left ventricular dysfunction. His electrocardiogram shows nonspecific ST segment depression, which may indicate ischemia or infarction. The patient is diagnosed with congestive heart failure (CHF) with reduced ejection fraction. The patient is admitted to the hospital for further management and treatment of his heart condition.

generated_summary: A 60-year-old male with a history of hypertension and diabetes presented with progressive shortness of breath over the past month. Echocardiogram showed reduced ejection fraction. He was started on diuretics and beta-blockers, and then switched to a new medication for heart failure. His condition worsened, prompting admission for further evaluation and treatment. The patient experienced dysuria, fever, and acute urinary retention, and was eventually diagnosed with urologic causes of his symptoms. He was treated with antibiotics and urinary catheters. The patient's current status includes dysuria, tenderness to the urethra region, increased urinary urgency, and fevers. The patient is currently being followed up with his primary care physician and neurosurgeon.

target: In brief this is a ___ year old male with dementia and CKD admitted for aggressive behavior. . #. Agressive behavior. Medical workup for delerium has been negative. Patient has been afebrile with an normal WBC and negative UA. Head CT showed no acute changes. Utox and Stox were negative. Renal function was at baseline. Most likely the agitation is secondary to patient's Alzheimer's dementia and worsening over two weeks prior to admission may be due to enviroment/medication changes. Psych was consulted and they recommended d/c all psychotropic drugs except olanzepine. The patient did very well with olanzapine (2.5 mg in am, 2.5 mg at 3 pm and 7.5 mg HS; also prn SL olanzepine q 4 hrs prn). For insomnia pt did well with an additional 2.5mh prn qhs dose in addition to his standing 7.5mg qhs dose. . Over the course of the 2 weeks prior to discharge, pt has made dramatic behavioral improvements. He has taken all of his standing olanzapine and has required very few prn doses (more for increased confusion than agitation) since ___. He continues to wander in the hallway, but does not wander into rooms other than his own. He continues to require a 1:1 sitter, but this is only because he is very disoriented and may otherwise wander off the floor since this unit is not locked. He has not displayed aggressive behavior towards staff these past 2 weeks. . It is important to note, that his behavioral decompensation prior leading to this admission was most likely the consequence of too frequent medication changes. We strongly advise adherence to the previously described olanzapine regimen as much as possible. His family is comfortable with the sedation caused by this regimen and understands that it is the trade-off necessary for better behavioral control. . #. Chronic constipation. Bowel regimen included ___ standing and bisacodyl prn. Fleet enemas may be used as needed. Pt perseverates on his bowel movements. He always complains of constipation, even after having adequate bowel movements. . #. CKD. Renal function was at baseline and remained throughout hospitalization. Slight intermittent elevations in creatinine responded well to encouraging increased po intake.
