OxyCODONE (Immediate Release) ___ mg PO Q4H: PRN Pain - Moderate RX *oxycodone 5 mg ___ tablet(s) by mouth every four (4) hours Disp #*20 Tablet Refills: *0 <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> Symptomatic cholelithiasis / cholecystitis <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> You were admitted to the hospital with acute cholecystitis. You were taken to the operating room and had your gallbladder removed laparoscopically. You tolerated the procedure well and are now being discharged home to continue your recovery with the following instructions. Please follow up in the Acute Care Surgery clinic at the appointment listed below. ACTIVITY: o Do not drive until you have stopped taking pain medicine and feel you could respond in an emergency. o You may climb stairs. o You may go outside, but avoid traveling long distances until you see your surgeon at your next visit. o Don't lift more than ___ lbs for 4 weeks. (This is about the weight of a briefcase or a bag of groceries.) This applies to lifting children, but they may sit on your lap. o You may start some light exercise when you feel comfortable. o You will need to stay out of bathtubs or swimming pools for a time while your incision is healing. Ask your doctor when you can resume tub baths or swimming. HOW YOU MAY FEEL: o You may feel weak or "washed out" for a couple of weeks. You might want to nap often. Simple tasks may exhaust you. o You may have a sore throat because of a tube that was in your throat during surgery. o You might have trouble concentrating or difficulty sleeping. You might feel somewhat depressed. o You could have a poor appetite for a while. Food may seem unappealing. o All of these feelings and reactions are normal and should go away in a short time. If they do not, tell your surgeon. YOUR INCISION: o Tomorrow you may shower and remove the gauzes over your incisions. Under these dressing you have small plastic bandages called steri-strips. Do not remove steri-strips for 2 weeks. (These are the thin paper strips that might be on your incision.) But if they fall off before that that's okay). o Your incisions may be slightly red around the stitches. This is normal. o You may gently wash away dried material around your incision. o Avoid direct sun exposure to the incision area. o Do not use any ointments on the incision unless you were told otherwise. o You may see a small amount of clear or light red fluid staining your dressing or clothes. If the staining is severe, please call your surgeon. o You may shower. As noted above, ask your doctor when you may resume tub baths or swimming. YOUR BOWELS: o Constipation is a common side effect of narcotic pain medications. If needed, you may take a stool softener (such as Colace, one capsule) or gentle laxative (such as milk of magnesia, 1 tbs) twice a day. You can get both of these medicines without a prescription. o If you go 48 hours without a bowel movement, or have pain moving the bowels, call your surgeon. PAIN MANAGEMENT: o It is normal to feel some discomfort/pain following abdominal surgery. This pain is often described as "soreness". o Your pain should get better day by day. If you find the pain is getting worse instead of better, please contact your surgeon. o You will receive a prescription for pain medicine to take by mouth. It is important to take this medicine as directed. o Do not take it more frequently than prescribed. Do not take more medicine at one time than prescribed. o Your pain medicine will work better if you take it before your pain gets too severe. o Talk with your surgeon about how long you will need to take prescription pain medicine. Please don't take any other pain medicine, including non-prescription pain medicine, unless your surgeon has said its okay. o If you are experiencing no pain, it is okay to skip a dose of pain medicine. o Remember to use your "cough pillow" for splinting when you cough or when you are doing your deep breathing exercises. If you experience any of the following, please contact your surgeon: - sharp pain or any severe pain that lasts several hours - pain that is getting worse over time - pain accompanied by fever of more than 101 - a drastic change in nature or quality of your pain MEDICATIONS: Take all the medicines you were on before the operation just as you did before, unless you have been told differently. If you have any questions about what medicine to take or not to take, please call your surgeon.
target: The patient was admitted to the General Surgical Service on ___ for evaluation and treatment of abdominal pain. Admission abdominal ultra-sound revealed cholelithiasis. The patient underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy, which went well without complication (reader referred to the Operative Note for details). After a brief, uneventful stay in the PACU, the patient arrived on the floor tolerating sips, on IV fluids, and IV analgesia for pain control. The patient was hemodynamically stable. . Pain was well controlled. Diet was progressively advanced as tolerated to a regular diet with good tolerability. The patient voided without problem. During this hospitalization, the patient ambulated early and frequently, was adherent with respiratory toilet and incentive spirometry, and actively participated in the plan of care. The patient received subcutaneous heparin and venodyne boots were used during this stay. . At the time of discharge, the patient was doing well, afebrile with stable vital signs. The patient was tolerating a regular diet, ambulating, voiding without assistance, and pain was well controlled. The patient was discharged home without services. The patient received discharge teaching and follow-up instructions with understanding verbalized and agreement with the discharge plan.
generated_summary: A 60-year-old man with a history of hypertension and diabetes presents with symptoms of acute cholecystitis. He underwent a laparoscopic cholecystectomy and experienced mild postoperative pain and discomfort. His vital signs are stable, and his physical examination shows no signs of infection or complications. The patient is advised to stop driving until he feels able to do so, to avoid heavy lifting, and to monitor his bowel movements closely. He is instructed to take pain medication as directed and to report any changes in his pain or any concerns to his surgeon. Follow-up appointments are scheduled to ensure that the wound heals properly and that the patient's condition improves.

Do not restart Potassium Chloride until instructed by your PCP ___: Home With Service Facility: ___ <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> - Secondary colon cancer - genetic polyposis - large paracolostomy hernia - post-operative ileus <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent. <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> Dear ___ ___ were admitted to the hospital after a completion colectomy for surgical management of your colon cancer. ___ have recovered from this procedure well and ___ are now ready to return home. Samples from your colon were taken and this tissue has been sent to the pathology department for analysis. ___ will receive these pathology results at your follow-up appointment. If there is an urgent need for the surgeon to contact ___ regarding these results they will contact ___ before this time. ___ have tolerated a regular diet, passing gas and your pain is controlled with pain medications by mouth. ___ may return home to finish your recovery. Please monitor your bowel function closely. ___ may or may not have had a bowel movement prior to your discharge which is acceptable; however it is important that ___ have a bowel movement in the next ___ days. After anesthesia it is not uncommon for patients to have some decrease in bowel function but ___ should not have prolonged constipation. Some loose stool and passing of small amounts of dark, old appearing blood are expected. However, if ___ notice that ___ are passing bright red blood with bowel movements or having large amounts of loose stool without improvement please call the office or go to the emergency room if the symptoms are severe. If ___ are taking narcotic pain medications there is a risk that ___ will have some constipation. Please take an over the counter stool softener such as Colace, and if the symptoms do not improve call the office. If ___ have any of the following symptoms please call the office for advice ___: fever greater than 101.5 increasing abdominal distension increasing abdominal pain nausea/vomiting inability to tolerate food or liquids prolonged loose stool extended constipation inability to urinate Incisions: ___ have a long vertical surgical incisions on your abdomen closed with staples. This is healing well, however, it is important that ___ monitor these areas for signs and symptoms of infection including: increasing redness of the incision lines, white/green/yellow/malodorous drainage, increased pain at the incision, increased warmth of the skin at the incision, or swelling of the area. ___ may shower; pat the incisions dry with a towel, do not rub. The small incisions may be left open to the air. If ___ have steri-strips (small white strips), they will fall off over time, please do not remove them. Please no baths or swimming until cleared by the surgical team. Pain: It is expected that ___ will have pain after surgery and this pain will gradually improve over the first week or so ___ are home. ___ will especially have pain when changing positions and with movement. ___ should continue to take 2 Extra Strength Tylenol (___) for pain every 8 hours around the clock. Please do not take more than 3000mg of Tylenol in 24 hours or any other medications that contain Tylenol such as cold medication. Do not drink alcohol while or Tylenol. ___ may also take Advil (Ibuprofen) 600mg every 8 hours for 7 days, please take Advil with food. If these medications are not controlling your pain to a point where ___ can ambulate and perform minor tasks, ___ should take a dose of the narcotic pain medication oxycodone. Please take this only if needed for pain. Do not take with any other sedating medications or alcohol. Do not drive a car if taking narcotic pain medications. Activity ___ may feel weak or "washed out" for up to 6 weeks after surgery. No heavy lifting greater than a gallon of milk for 3 weeks. At your first follow up appointment, your surgical team will clear ___ for heavier exercise and activity as they observe your progress. In the meantime, ___ may climb stairs, and go outside and walk. Please avoid traveling long distances until ___ speak with your surgical team at your post-op visit. Again, please do not drive while taking narcotic pain medications. ___ have a new ileostomy. The most common complication from a new ileostomy placement is dehydration. Stool is no longer passing through the large intestine which is where water is reabsorbed into the body and the stool becomes formed. However, the output from your stoma (intestine that protrudes outside of your abdomen) will be watery because it is coming from the small intestine which means the water is not reabsorbed by the colon. ___ must measure your ileostomy output for the next few weeks. The output should not be more than 1200cc or less than 500cc. If ___ find that your output has become too much or too little, please call the office. The office nurse or nurse practitioner can recommend medications to increase or slow the ileostomy output. Keep yourself well hydrated, if ___ notice your ileostomy output increasing, drink liquids with electrolytes such as Gatorade. Please monitor for signs and symptoms of dehydration including: dry mouth or tongue, decrease in urination, urine darker in color, dizziness especially when ___ stand, cramps in your abdomen or legs, increased thirst, or weakness. If ___ notice these symptoms please call the office or return to the emergency room for evaluation if these symptoms are severe. ___ may eat a regular diet with your new ileostomy. However, it is a good idea to avoid fatty or spicy foods and follow diet suggestions made to ___ by the ostomy nurses. ___ monitor the appearance of your stoma and care for it as instructed by the ostomy nurses. ___ stoma should be beefy red or pink, it may ooze small amounts of blood at times when touched but this will improve over time. The skin around the ostomy site should be kept clean and intact. Monitor the skin around the stoma for any bulging or signs of infection listed above. ___ will be able to make an appointment with the ostomy nurse in the clinic ___ weeks after surgery. Please call the ostomy nurses clinic number which is listed in the ileostomy/colostomy handout packet given to ___ by the nursing staff. ___ will also have a visiting nurse at home for the next few weeks to help to monitor your ostomy until ___ are comfortable caring for it on your own. Follow-up: 1. ___ will need to follow up with both General surgery and Plastic surgery. 2. ___ will need to follow up with your primary care doctor within 1 - 2 weeks, so he can determine which of your home blood pressure medications that ___ should resume. 3. ___ will need an spleen ultra-sound in 3 months to evaluate lesions found on your spleen. Our hope is that ___ will have a quick return to your life and usual activities. Thank ___ for allowing us to participate in your care!
target: Mr. ___ is a ___ who underwent an exploratory laparotomy in conjunction with abdominal wall reconstruction and completion colectomy and end ileostomy. He was initially admitted to the plastic surgery service on ___ however was transferred to ___ on ___. Neuro: Post-operatively, the patient received dilaudid PCA with good effect and adequate pain control. When tolerating oral intake on, the patient was transitioned to oral pain medications. CV: The patient was stable from a cardiovascular standpoint and monitored for afib with telemetry. Course was notable for multiple bouts of tachycardia (Afib RVR) associated with physical activity with HR in the 130s-150s. BP remained stable during these episodes and tachycardia self-resolved with rest. This improved with continued physical therapy and initiation of home beta blocker (IV metoprolol when NPO, then PO atenolol). Patient was restarted on home atenolol for rate control and rivaroxaban for AC. Patient also with a longstanding history of hypertension. He was continued on a clonidine patch inpatient but home amlodipine, lisinopril, and furosemide were held due to normotension. Patient will follow up with PCP prior to restarting. Pulmonary: The patient has history of asthma and was started on home asthma medications or substitutes. Patient fairly non-compliant with use of CPAP which was available. GI/GU: #Ileus: On POD patient was kept NPO and started on IVF. He was advanced to sips on POD#2 and then to clear liquids on POD#3. Foley was maintained until POD#2 and then discontinued. Foley catheter was placed in ostomy with small liquid stool and gas output. In addition, urine output was noted to be marginal so patient was given albumin for concern for intravascular dehydration. POD#5 showed good stoma function with stoma catheter in place and patient was advanced to a regular diet. On POD#6, the stoma catheter was discontinued. Patient had no ostomy output and very poor urine output on POD#7. He was also noted to have nausea and a distended abdomen. KUB revealed ileus and gastroparesis. Ostomy stoma was catheterized again and an NG tube was placed with immediate output of 3 liters of green fluid. Patient was made NPO and placed back on IV fluids. generated_summary: A 45-year-old woman presents with worsening back pain due to metastatic breast cancer, and imaging shows thoracic spine fractures. She receives palliative radiation therapy and undergoes a completion colectomy for surgical management of her colon cancer. Her colon cancer was diagnosed 2 years ago, and she has a history of hypertension and diabetes. She underwent total colectomy with end ileostomy, and is now recovering from the surgery. Her current medications include albuterol inhaler, allopurinol, amoxicillin, atenolol, budesonide nasal inhaler, clopidogrel, rivaroxaban, vitamin D, and Tylenol. She is advised to monitor her bowel function closely and avoid driving while taking narcotic pain medications.

generated_summary: A 60-year-old man with a history of hypertension and diabetes presents with progressive shortness of breath over the past month, reduced ejection fraction, and elevated lactate levels. His echocardiogram shows a severe left ventricular dysfunction with global hypokinesis and inferior/lateral thinning/akinesis. He is being treated with metoprolol succinate, spironolactone, and finasteride, and is being discharged home on these medications. His family member accompanies him to the hospital and takes notes throughout the visit.

target: The patient was admitted for evaluation and management of her facial pain. MRI/MRA/MRV brain was unremarkable, and the etiology of the pain was thought to be a combination of trigeminal neuralgia, temperomandibular joint disease, and migraine. The patient frequently demanded narcotics during her admission, reporting that "nothing works except dilaudid (or IV medications)." She was noted to complain of significantly more discomfort when medical personnel were in the room. There had apparently been some concern for drug-seeking behavior in the past. One-time doses of dilaudid 2mg were given several times when the patient complained of severe pain; she also received morphine and ativan due to pain and anxiety prior to her MRI. She was started on oxcarbazepine (Trileptal) for pain control of trigeminal neuralgia. She was discharged with a prescription for oxcarbazepine as well as dilaudid 2mg PRN (3 tabs total), with instructions to follow-up with pain clinic and dental surgery. The MRI/MRA/MRV was discussed with neuroradiology prior to discharge, but the final read is pending.
generated_summary: A 60-year-old male with a history of hypertension and diabetes presented with progressive shortness of breath over the past month. Echocardiogram showed a reduced ejection fraction. He was started on diuretics and beta-blockers. His cardiology team planned for close outpatient follow-up.

The patient was advised to exercise regularly and maintain a low-cholesterol diet to reduce his risk of cardiovascular events.

For a full detailed history of the patient's lung cancer, please see ___ note from ___. In brief, most recently in ___, the patient had a CT chest which showed a 1.3 x 1.0 cm right lower lobe lung nodule, increased from 1.0 x 0.4 cm, thought to be most likely bronchogenic carcinoma. On ___ the patient had a CT guided RFA of this lesion. The procedure was complicated by a small amount of hemorrhage, and a small pneumothorax, so a biopsy of the lesion was not obtained. Ms. ___ was admitted to ___ from ___ to ___ with respiratory failure after the RFA. She was treated with Levaquin for pneumonia. Her oxygenation improved and she was discharged to ___ in ___, where she stayed for two weeks. A follow up CT with contrast on ___ showed a cavitary nodule in the medial RLL significantly increased to 3.4 x 3.7 cm compared with 2.3 cm with central low density suggesting necrosis. The nodule abutted the esophagus and posterior pericardium without definite evidence of invasion. Given the location of the patient's lesion, it was not felt to be amenable to a wedge resection, but would rather require a basal segmentectomy. However, it was also thought to be amenable to CyberKnife SBRT which would require biopsy and fiducial marker placement. On ___, she underwent outpatient biopsy & fiducial placement of RLL lung mass. 4 core biopsy samples were sent for pathology, and 10cc of purulent fluid were sent for microbiology. A CT showed a small paramediastinal pneumothorax post-procedure, with follow up CXRs at 2 and 4 hours post procedure showing resolution of the PTX. Clinically, she has been stable on room air. Upon arrival to the floor, the patient reports that her breathing is at baseline with no shortness of breath. She states that the procedure was quite painful, but that she no longer has any pain. She was found to also have R arm and leg weakness at ___. She has been ambulating without difficulty since discharge. The most disturbing residual effect is bilateral foot tingling in the soles, which has not improved since discharge. This sensation makes it difficult to walk because it feels like her feet are not her own. Per ___ discharge paperwork, patient was diagnosed with MS. ___ was 5 day course of IV steroids and was prescribed Copaxone, which she has not started because of insurance issues. She also reports an episode of "vertigo" ___. She was standing and suddenly got the sensation of swaying, then on turning nearly fell over. A similar episode occurred this morning, she felt a sensation of vertical motion while seated. She has also been more fatigued with exertion and diaphoretic. generated_summary: A 60-year-old male with a history of hypertension and diabetes presents with progressive shortness of breath over the past month. He underwent echocardiography showing reduced ejection fraction. The patient's anxiety and migraines were managed with Aleve and metrolane respectively. His MS diagnosis was confirmed by EEG and MRI findings. The patient was admitted to the hospital for further management of his condition and underwent imaging studies including CT scans of the head and neck, which revealed multiple sclerosis lesions in the thoracic spine. The patient was discharged home with ongoing treatment for MS and continued monitoring for potential complications.

target: Mr. ___ is a ___ gentleman who is 4 weeks s/p total pancreatectomy (complete pancreatectomy, total splenectomy, partial duodenectomy, partial gastrectomy, islet cell re-implantation) complicated by bacteremia (enterobacter) and two abdominal abscesses 1.5 weeks ago who presented with several days of nausea/vomiting on oral antibiotics. # Nausea/vomiting: The patient was evaluated for common etiologies of nausea/vomiting. Obstruction was not likely given his relatively benign exam and history recent bowel movements. Recurrence of his intrabdominal infection was less unlikely given no recent fevers or changes in output from his drains and improved WBC count. Gastroenteritis also unlikely, given no recent sick contacts and improvement with IV abx. His symptoms are most likely related to recent changes to PO medication list, notably a switch from IV to PO ciprofloxacin, flagyl, and fluconazole. A review of OSH records and discussion with the attending surgeon (Dr. ___ at ___ clarified antibiotic requirement. The patient had documented ciprofloxacin-sensitive E. aerogenes (GNR) bacteremia secondary to a PICC line, however patient has been on fluconazole and flagyl for 2 weeks without a clear target. The outpatient surgery team and inpatient medicine team agreed the fluconazole and flagyl could be discontinued given lack of culture data or clinical suspicion supporting their use beyond two weeks. The patient was switched to PO ciprofloxacin only, and allowed to progress his diet as tolerated. The patient did not feel nausea with the PO ciprofloxacin and progressed from a clear liquid, full liquid, to a regular diet by the time of discharge. He also gained weight during his recovery. PICC line placement was discussed with the patient, but given his tolerating PO ciprofloxacin, his progressing diet, and his gaining weight, this was not pursued, especially given his recent PICC-line associated bacteremia and splenectomy making TPN high risk. The patient was given a bowel regimen and was stooling comfortably before discharge. # Failure to thrive: The patient reports poor PO intake since before his pancreatectomy. Given improving PO intake and recent bacteremia, it was decided not to start TPN during this admission. The patient was seen by nutrition and caloric intake and his daily weights were monitored. By the time of discharge, his weight was stable on regular diabetic diet. # Total pancreatectomy: The patient's two JP drains were left in place. The patient was continued on his prescribed insulin replacement therapy. The patient was given his oxycontin dose for pain. The patient's pain was well-controlled and by the end of his hospitalization, his oxycontin dose was decreased to 30mg BID. The patient was also continued on his PPI. # Thrombocytosis: The patient was admitted with platelets over 1000. This is most likely reactive in the setting of recent surgery and due to splenectomy. His PLT count was downtrending through his stay and he was continued on his ASA 325mg. # Anxiety: The patient was treated with his home dosing of Escitalopram. Vitamin D ___ UNIT PO DAILY <DISCHARGE DISPOSITION> Home With Service Facility: ___ <DISCHARGE DIAGNOSIS> right hip OA <DISCHARGE CONDITION> Mental Status: Clear and coherent. Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive. Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker or cane). <FOLLOWUP INSTRUCTIONS> ___ <DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS> 1. Please return to the emergency department or notify your physician if you experience any of the following: severe pain not relieved by medication, increased swelling, decreased sensation, difficulty with movement, fevers greater than 101.5, shaking chills, increasing redness or drainage from the incision site, chest pain, shortness of breath or any other concerns. 2. Please follow up with your primary physician regarding this admission and any new medications and refills. 3. Resume your home medications unless otherwise instructed. 4. You have been given medications for pain control. Please do not drive, operate heavy machinery, or drink alcohol while taking these medications. As your pain decreases, take fewer tablets and increase the time between doses. This medication can cause constipation, so you should drink plenty of water daily and take a stool softener (such as Colace) as needed to prevent this side effect. Call your surgeons office 3 days before you are out of medication so that it can be refilled. These medications cannot be called into your pharmacy and must be picked up in the clinic or mailed to your house. Please allow an extra 2 days if you would like your medication mailed to your home. 5. You may not drive a car until cleared to do so by your surgeon. 6. generated_summary: A 60-year-old male with a history of hypertension and diabetes presented with progressive shortness of breath over the past month. He underwent echocardiogram showing reduced ejection fraction and had a cardiac catheterization that was unchanged. He was diagnosed with atrial fibrillation, rheumatoid arthritis, gout, and osteoporosis. His current medication regimen included coumadin, lasix, spirinolactone, Prednisone, and Metoprolol Succinate. He was admitted to the hospital due to worsening symptoms and was found to be in congestive heart failure. A CT scan of his lungs showed fluid overload, and he was given diuretics and increased his Coumadin and Lasix doses. The patient's condition was stabilized, but he required ongoing monitoring of his blood pressure and electrolyte levels. His discharge instructions included weighing himself daily and contacting his physician if his weight went above 3 pounds.

target: Ms. ___ was admitted for diagnosis and treatment of her shortness of breath. She remained afebrile. Outside records were obtained from ___ and CXR showed evidence of possible pulm edema. # Shortness of breath: DDx was broad, given hx of RA and immunosuppresion. Pleuritic chest pain was thought to be radiation from lung process (given negative extremity exam). CAP was considered most likely etiology of SOB. Less likely etiologies included: legionella (esp considering hyponatremia although urine ag negative)), TB (no hx of exposure, prior PPD negative). She was also treated for pulm edema suggested by CXR (however, echo was not consistent with CHF and EKG not suggestive of MI/ACS as cause of CHF). Her leukocytosis resolved (16.3-->10.8) on Levofloxacin. Pt also rec'd Lasix w good urine output. Crackles improved on hospital day 3. - Levofloxacin to 750mg PO per day for CAP (___) Inactive Issues: #Macrocytosis Likely ___ MTX therapy. B12 and folate wnl. # RA: Followed by rheumatologist. generated_summary: A 60-year-old man presents with progressive shortness of breath over the past month. He underwent echocardiogram showing reduced ejection fraction. The patient was started on diuretics and beta-blockers. Cardiology team planned for close outpatient follow-up.
